Description: STUDENTS IN GRADES 6-12 WILL PARTICIPATE IN OVER 300 HOURS OF OUTDOOR EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES THAT INCLUDES A 3-5 DAY IMMERSIVE HUAKAI (TRIP) EXPERIENCE IN VARIOUS WATERSHEDS ON OAHU WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS AND CULTURAL EXPERTS. TEACHERS AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS WILL COLLABORATE IN DEVELOPING AND DELIVERING CURRICULUM THAT INTEGRATES CULTURE, AINA (LAND), AND ACADEMIC CONTENT, AND PLACES HAWAIIAN STORIES, PRACTICES, VALUES AND WORLDVIEW AT THE CENTER OF LEARNING. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DETERMINE THE IMPACT ON ENVIRONMENTAL AND WATERSHED EDUCATION BY INCORPORATING CULTURAL AND AINA-BASED EXPERIENCES WITH SCIENCE AND OTHER ACADEMIC SUBJECTS.

THIS AWARD PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS DEPARTMENT OF PLANNING AND NATURAL RESOURCES, DIVISION OF COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT TO ORGANIZED AND HOLD THE 47TH U.S. CORAL REEF TASK FORCE MEETING IN ST. THOMAS, U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS IN THE FALL OF 2023. THE MEETING PROVIDES AN OPPORTUNITY FOR TASK FORCE MEMBERS TO WORK TOGETHER TOWARDS HEALTHY AND PRODUCTIVE CORAL REEF ECOSYSTEMS IN THE FACE OF CURRENT CHALLENGES FROM CLIMATE CHANGE AND HUMAN USES. ISLAND ECOSYSTEMS ARE OFTEN AT THE FOREFRONT OF CLIMATE RELATED CHANGES SUCH AS SEA LEVEL RISE AND THE INCREASED FREQUENCY OF STORM EVENTS, SO HOSTING EVENTS LIKE THE U.S. CORAL REEF TASK FORCE MEETING IN THE VIRGIN ISLANDS WILL ALLOW LOCAL MANAGERS TO SHOWCASE NEEDS AND PRIORITIES TO FEDERAL PARTNERS IN REAL TIME AND IN PERSON, WHICH WILL HOPEFULLY LEAD TO CREATIVE AND COLLABORATIVE SOLUTIONS TO THESE ISSUES.

IN 2021 AND 2022, THE CITIES INITIATIVE CONTRIBUTED IN-KIND DIRECT SUPPORT TO THE LAKE MICHIGAN COASTAL RESILIENCE INITIATIVE (LMCRI), GIVING AN ESTIMATED 100-150 HOURS OF STAFF TIME IN PROJECT DESIGN, CITY ENGAGEMENT, EDUCATIONAL WEBINARS AND DISSEMINATION OF THE PROJECT THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF WEB-BASED CONTENT. THE CITIES INITIATIVE IS SEEKING FUNDING TO SUPPORT ITS CONTINUED INVOLVEMENT IN THE LMCRI AND FUTURE COASTAL RESILIENCE INITIATIVE CYCLES. AS OF JANUARY 2023, THE LMCRI IS SUPPORTING EIGHT COMMUNITIES IN ILLINOIS, MICHIGAN AND WISCONSIN TO 30%-80% ENGINEERING AND DESIGN THROUGH THE END OF 2023. NOAA AND THE CITIES INITIATIVE ANTICIPATE SUPPORTING 8-12 COMMUNITIES THROUGH THE LMCRI AND SUBSEQUENT COASTAL RESILIENCE INITIATIVES PER CYCLE WHICH WILL REQUIRE A DEDICATED TEAM OF PARTNERS TO SUCCESSFULLY DESIGN, DELIVER AND EVALUATE THESE PROGRAMS. NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $2,962,196.00 TO THE VIEQUES CONSERVATION AND HISTORICAL TRUST UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION.  THIS AWARD WILL RESULT ON RESTORATION OF IMPORTANT INTERCONNECTED COASTAL HABITATS, INCLUDING THE CONTINUUM OF MANGROVES CRITICAL FOR THE CONSERVATION OF THE BIOLUMINESCENT BAY, SEAGRASS COMMUNITIES AND CORAL REEFS TO PROMOTE ENHANCED ECOLOGICAL CONNECTIVITY, THE REHABILITATION OF IMPORTANT ECOSYSTEM FUNCTIONS, AND BUFFERING THE COASTAL IMPACTS OF STORM SURGE DURING EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS. IN ADDITION TO THESE LOCAL BENEFITS, THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE IMPORTANT BENEFITS TO REGIONAL CONSERVATION OF COASTAL NATURAL RESOURCES BY PROMOTING THE CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION OF A UNIQUE COMBINATION OF INTERCONNECTED HABITATS FOR THE CONSERVATION OF MULTIPLE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT-LISTED SPECIES, AMONG THEM, CORAL SPECIES, AND THE PUERTO MOSQUITO BIOLUMINESCENT BA

NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $203,000 TO THE AMERICAN SAMOA GOVERNMENT DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION. THIS AWARD WILL SUPPORT CONTINUED WETLAND DELINEATION TO INCLUDE ALL WETLANDS IN THE TERRITORY, PLUS MONTHLY WETLAND MONITORING, PARTNER TRAINING, AND COMMUNITY OUTREACH WORKSHOPS IN AMERICAN SAMOA. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT ECOSYSTEMS AND COMMUNITIES BY HELPING THE COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM AND THEIR PARTNERS TO BETTER MANAGE, PROTECT, AND ENHANCE WETLANDS AND EDUCATE THE COMMUNITY ABOUT THE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES THESE NATURAL RESOURCES PROVIDE. PROJECT OUTCOMES ALSO INCLUDE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR SUPPORTING UPDATED LAND USE PERMITTING POLICIES AND REGULATIONS, AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR NATURE-BASED RESTORATION PROJECTS IN EACH WETLAND VILLAGE.

VIRGINIA EELGRASS & BAY SCALLOP RESTORATION PROPOSAL    RECIPIENT: VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY PERIOD: APRIL 1, 2023 TO MARCH 31, 2027 RECOMMENDED FEDERAL FUNDING: $2,259,633 CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT(S): VA-2 SUMMARY: BUILDING ON THE KNOWLEDGE GAINED FROM THE SUCCESSFUL EELGRASS AND BAY SCALLOP RESTORATION IN SOUTHERN VIRGINIA'S COASTAL BAYS, THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON BURTONS BAY. PROJECT IMPACTS WILL BE MONITORED TO SEE IF THE PROJECTIONS (ENHANCED WATER CLARITY, CREATION OF CARBON STOCKS, INCREASED PRODUCTIVITY OF COMMERCIALLY HARVESTED SPECIES) ARE REALIZED. OVER A FOUR-YEAR PERIOD, AT LEAST 60 ACRES OF EELGRASS WILL BE PLANTED AND OVER SIX MILLION BAY SCALLOPS RELEASED. LONG- TERM MONITORING IS ALSO PART OF THIS PROJECT, AS IS AN EDUCATION COMPONENT. THE DESIRED END RESULT: A HEALTHY AND EXPANDING EELGRASS MEADOW AND A RESIDENT SCALLOP POPULATION IN BURTONS BAY.

NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $4,500,000 TO THE SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROL UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION.  CONSERVATION PARTNERS WILL USE THESE FUNDS TO OBTAIN KEY FLOODPLAIN PROPERTIES WITHIN TWO COASTAL COUNTIES FOR A NEW STATE PARK. TO DATE, FIVE STRATEGIC RIVERFRONT PROPERTIES TOTALING 2,500 ACRES HAVE BEEN SECURED. ACQUISITION OF THIS 1,800-ACRE TRACT IS NEXT. THIS PROPERTY CREATES A WALKABLE CONNECTION TO A RURAL TOWN THAT HAS EXPERIENCED BOTH EXTREME FLOOD DAMAGE AND INCREASING POVERTY IN RECENT YEARS. THE TOWN OF ANDREWS IS CURRENTLY ENGAGED IN A MAIN STREET VISIONING AND MASTER PLANNING PROCESS TO LINK THEIR ECONOMIC FUTURE TO THE NEW PARK, AND TO THE BLACK RIVER ITSELF. THE OPEN SPACE INSTITUTE LAND TRUST INTENDS TO ACQUIRE THE PROPERTY ON BEHALF OF THE SOUTH CAROLINA PARKS RECREATION AND TOURISM FOR THE NEWLY ESTABLISHED BLACK RIVER

NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $2,988,122 TO THE NEW HAMPSHIRE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION. THIS AWARD WILL RESULT IN THE REPLACEMENT OF THREE UNDERSIZED TIDAL CULVERTS ON STATE ROADS IN THE TOWNS OF STRATHAM AND RYE, NEW HAMPSHIRE. REPAIRING THESE TIDAL CROSSINGS WAS IDENTIFIED AS A HIGH PRIORITY VIA THE NEW HAMPSHIRE RESILIENT TIDAL CROSSINGS PROJECT, WHICH SCORED 118 TIDAL CROSSINGS FOR ECOSYSTEM COMPATIBILITY, FLOOD RESILIENCE, AND STRUCTURE CONDITION. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL INCLUDE FINAL ENGINEERING AND PERMITTING WORK, AND WILL PROACTIVELY REPLACE THE EXISTING CULVERTS AT THESE SITES WITH UPGRADED ALTERNATIVES TO ACHIEVE BENEFICIAL OUTCOMES FOR ECOSYSTEM AND INFRASTRUCTURE RESILIENCY.

NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $3,037,052 TO THE UPPER MATTAPONI INDIAN TRIBE UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION.  THE UPPER MATTAPONI INDIAN TRIBE, THROUGH THE VIRGINIA COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, WILL ACQUIRE AND CONSERVE 866 ACRES (THREE ADJACENT PARCELS) OF HISTORIC TRIBAL LANDS ALONG THE TRIBE'S NAMESAKE RIVER, THE MATTAPONI, AND WITHIN THE CHESAPEAKE BAY WATERSHED. THIS IS THE TRIBE'S FIRST OPPORTUNITY TO ACQUIRE ANCESTRAL LANDS FOR CONSERVATION, AND WILL ALLOW THE TRIBE TO PURSUE FUTURE ACTIVITIES TO ENHANCE CULTURALLY SIGNIFICANT FISH, WILDLIFE, AND PLANTS THROUGH HABITAT RESTORATION ON THE SITE OF A FORMER SAND AND GRAVEL MINE. THE BENEFITS WILL EXTEND TO TRIBAL CITIZENS AND MANY OTHERS WHO ENJOY THE REGION'S COAST.

NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $1,705,000 TO THE OHIO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES OFFICE OF COASTAL MANAGEMENT UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION. FUNDS FROM THIS GRANT WILL BE USED TO ACQUIRE 105 ACRES OF RIPARIAN HABITAT ALONG THE CHAGRIN RIVER IN A COASTAL COMMUNITY APPROXIMATELY FOUR MILES UPSTREAM FROM THE CONFLUENCE WITH LAKE ERIE. THE CHAGRIN RIVER FLOODPLAIN LAND CONSERVATION PROJECT WILL ACQUIRE CRITICAL HABITAT THAT WILL INCREASE CLIMATE RESILIENCY FOR URBAN COASTAL COMMUNITIES AND WILL CONTRIBUTE TO A GROWING CONSERVATION, PUBLIC ACCESS, AND RECREATION CORRIDOR ALONG THE RIVER FROM DOWNTOWN WILLOUGHBY TO LAKE ERIE. THIS IS A PARTNERSHIP EFFORT BETWEEN THE OHIO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES OFFICE OF COASTAL MANAGEMENT, THE CITY OF WILLOUGHBY, AND THE WESTERN RESERVE LAND CONSERVANCY.

NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $1,561,511 TO THE MASSACHUSETTS EXECUTIVE OFFICE OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL AFFAIRS UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION. THIS AWARD SUPPORTS HABITAT RESTORATION AND FISH PASSAGE WHILE INCREASING RESILIENCY FOR THE TOWN OF MANCHESTER-BY-THE-SEA. THE PROJECT INCLUDES REPLACING THE CENTRAL STREET BRIDGE, REMOVING THE SAWMILL BROOK TIDE GATE STRUCTURE, UPGRADING CHANNEL WALLS ALONG CENTRAL POND, RESTORING SALTMARSH WETLANDS, AND CREATING LIVING SHORELINES TO STABILIZE THE STREAM BANKS. ONE ACRE OF SALT MARSH AND 1,534 LINEAR FEET OF STREAM CONNECTIVITY WILL BE RESTORED, WHICH IN TURN IMPROVES RESILIENCY FOR THE SAWMILL BROOK WATERSHED AND THE MANCHESTER-BY-THE-SEA COMMUNITY.

THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $1,654,680 TO THE MAINE DEPARTMENT OF MARINE RESOURCES UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION. THE MAINE COASTAL PROGRAM (WITHIN THE MAINE DEPARTMENT OF MARINE RESOURCES), ALONG WITH OTHER COASTAL PARTNERS, WILL APPLY INNOVATIVE, SCIENCE-BASED BEST APPROACHES (REFERRED TO AS "COASTWISE") TO PLAN AND DESIGN COASTAL INFRASTRUCTURE IMPROVEMENTS. THE PROJECT FEATURES A COLLABORATIVE, LOCALLY-LED PROCESS TO PRODUCE PRELIMINARY DESIGNS FOR BARRIER REMOVAL AT SIX TIDAL CROSSINGS, AND FINAL DESIGNS FOR FOUR OF THOSE. THE APPLICATION OF THE COASTWISE PRINCIPLES TO THIS PROJECT WILL SERVE AS A MODEL FOR HOW THE APPROACH CAN BE USED TO DEVELOP RESILIENT TIDAL CROSSINGS ON A MUCH LARGER SCALE THAN PREVIOUSLY POSSIBLE. NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $1,103,000 TO ALABAMA DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION AND NATURAL RESOURCES UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION. THIS AWARD WILL RESULT IN THE FEE SIMPLE ACQUISITION OF APPROXIMATELY 490 ACRES OF CRITICAL HABITAT TO BE HELD BY THE ALABAMA DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION AND NATURAL RESOURCES, STATE LANDS DIVISION. THIS PURCHASE WILL CONSERVE THE TIDAL MARSH, PINE FLATWOOD, AND SAVANNA HABITATS LOCATED HERE, ALL OF WHICH REPRESENTS A CRITICALLY IMPERILED TYPE OF HABITAT FOUND ALONG THE NORTHERN GULF OF MEXICO. THE ACQUISITION WILL PROTECT THESE SENSITIVE HABITATS AND THE MYRIAD ECOSYSTEM SERVICES PROVIDED, SUCH AS THE AREA ACTING AS A HABITAT AND NURSERY GROUND FOR COMMERCIALLY AND RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT FISHERY SPECIES; PROTECTING UPLANDS FROM STORM SURGE AND COASTAL FLOODING; AND PROVIDING CARBON SEQUESTRATION SERVICES.

NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $6,000,000 TO THE FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION. THIS AWARD WILL FUND THE ACQUISITION OF A PORTION OF THE REMAINING, PRIVATELY-OWNED 10,976 ACRES OF THE 73,400-ACRE NORTHEAST FLORIDA BLUEWAY PROJECT, WHICH IS ON THE FLORIDA FOREVER PROGRAM'S CLIMATE CHANGE LANDS LIST. MOST OF THE ACQUISITION IS WITHIN THE BOUNDARIES OF THE GUANA TOLOMATO MATANZAS NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE. ACQUIRING THIS ACREAGE WILL PROTECT AND MAINTAIN THE WATERS AND SHORELINE PLANT COMMUNITIES OF THE TOLOMATO AND MATANZAS RIVERS, WHICH PROVIDES CRITICAL HABITAT FOR 14 FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES OF FISH, AMPHIBIAN, REPTILES, BIRDS, MAMMALS, AND PLANTS. THIS ACQUISITION WILL ALSO CONNECT EXISTING NATURAL AREAS TO FORM A CONSERVATION CORRIDOR AND WATERSHED BUFFER ALONG THE INTRACOASTAL WATERWAY IN NORTHEAST FLORIDA, FROM DUVAL

NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $2,011,465 TO THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF LAND CONSERVATION AND DEVELOPMENT UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION. THE CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF SILETZ INDIANS WILL PURCHASE THE ECOLOGICALLY AND CULTURALLY SIGNIFICANT 27-ACRE "'CAPE FOULWEATHER"' PROPERTY, LOCATED ON A BLUFF OVERLOOKING THE PACIFIC OCEAN. THIS PROJECT WILL CONSERVE THE UNDEVELOPED COASTAL PROPERTY THAT HOSTS ROCKY SHORE HABITATS RICH IN MARINE MAMMALS, A RARE SALT SPRAY MEADOW COMPLEX SUITABLE FOR THE THREATENED OREGON SILVERSPOT BUTTERFLY, AND UPLAND FOREST CONNECTIONS TO STRONGHOLDS OF MARBLED MURRELET, SPOTTED OWL, AND OTHER PACIFIC NORTHWEST ICONS. THE HEADLAND IS ALSO A HIGHLY VISIBLE FEATURE FROM AFAR, PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR PUBLIC EDUCATION AND OUTREACH ABOUT THE RICHNESS OF THE OREGON COAST, THE CENTRAL ROLE OF THE TRIBES IN ITS STEWARDSHIP, AND THE VALUE OF MAINTA

NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $1,965,000 TO THE WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF ADMINISTRATION UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION. BAYFIELD COUNTY WILL ACQUIRE 2,001 ACRES OF LAND WITH ECOLOGICALLY SIGNIFICANT HABITAT THAT IS VITAL TO THE HEALTH AND FUNCTIONING OF LAKE SUPERIOR'S COASTAL RESOURCES. THE MAJORITY OF THE 2,001 ACRES ARE FORESTED, WITH 180 ACRES OF WETLANDS AND SIX ACRES OF WATER, INCLUDING TWO MILES OF THE SAND RIVER AND NEARLY EIGHT MILES OF TRIBUTARIES AND FEEDER STREAMS OF THE SAND AND SISKIWIT RIVERS. THESE FOREST, WETLAND, AND RIPARIAN ECOSYSTEMS PROVIDE STOPOVER HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY BIRDS, SPAWNING AREAS FOR GREAT LAKES FISH, AESTHETIC VIEWS OF LAKE SUPERIOR, AND PASSIVE RECREATION POTENTIAL.

NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $147,000 TO THE ALABAMA DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION AND NATURAL RESOURCES UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION.  THIS AWARD WILL RESULT IN THE FEE SIMPLE ACQUISITION OF THE APPROXIMATELY 40-ACRE MAURY TRACT WITHIN THE MEADOWS MANAGEMENT UNIT OF THE WEEKS BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE IN FAIRHOPE, BALDWIN COUNTY, ALABAMA. THE ACQUISITION WILL HELP PROTECT THE ECOLOGICAL INTEGRITY OF THE AREA AND IMPORTANT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, SUCH AS ACTING AS A BUFFER FOR STORM SURGE AND COASTAL FLOODING; PROVIDING SPACE FOR MARSH MIGRATION; PROVIDING CARBON SEQUESTRATION SERVICES; AND THE ONGOING MAINTENANCE OF WATER QUALITY. THIS PROJECT WILL COMPLEMENT PREVIOUS ACQUISITION AND MANAGEMENT EFFORTS IN THE MEADOWS UNIT AND IS ALIGNED WITH THE ACQUISITION AND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES OUTLINED IN THE 2017 TO 2022 MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR THE RESEARCH RESERVE. NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $620,313.00 TO THE SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION. THIS RESTORATION PROJECT WILL ADDRESS SALT MARSH EROSION AND HABITAT LOSS, AND GENERATE ESSENTIAL FISH HABITAT BY CREATING INTERTIDAL OYSTER REEFS. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO PROMOTE SALT MARSH STEWARDSHIP BY ENGAGING VARIOUS STAKEHOLDER GROUPS IN THIS THREE-YEAR EFFORT. THE SUCCESS OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE MEASURED BY THE SUCCESS OF THE OYSTER REEF HABITAT AND THE SHORELINE STABILIZATION THE OYSTER REEF WILL PROVIDE. SUCCESS WILL ALSO BE MEASURED BY THE NUMBER OF VOLUNTEERS INVOLVED IN THE REEF INSTALLATIONS, SALT MARSH PLANTING, AND NATURAL HABITAT ACCRETION. THE SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES WILL CONDUCT THIS PROJECT WITHIN THE ACE BASIN NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE.

TITLE: JUG BAY WETLANDS SANCTUARY STREAM AND SHORELINE RESTORATION, PHASE I RECIPIENT: MARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (CHESAPEAKE BAY NERR - MD) PERIOD: 04/01/2023 TO- 04/01/2026 RECOMMENDED FEDERAL FUNDING: $992,728.00 CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT(S): THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE CREATION OF A FRESHWATER TIDAL MARSH LIVING SHORELINE AND THE RESTORATION OF THREE SEVERELY INCISED HEADWATER STREAMS COUPLED WITH THE INSTALLATION OF UPLAND STORMWATER BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES IN THE JUG BAY WETLANDS SANCTUARY IN ANNE ARUNDEL COUNTY, MD. THE SHORELINE WORK WILL PROTECT SANCTUARY PROPERTY FROM EROSION AND ENHANCE THE TIDAL MARSH'S RESILIENCE TO SEA LEVEL RISE AND CLIMATE HAZARDS. THE STREAM RESTORATION AND STORMWATER BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES WILL SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCE THE AMOUNT OF SEDIMENT AND NUTRIENT POLLUTION GOING INTO CHESAPEAKE BAY WHILE RECONNECTING STREAMS WITH THEIR FLOODPLAINS TO ENHANCE RESILIENCE TO INCREASED RAINFALL INTENSITY.

NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $199,959 TO THE RHODE ISLAND DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION. THIS AWARD WILL SUPPORT THE DESIGN AND PERMITTING PHASES OF PROJECTS THAT PROTECT IMPORTANT COASTAL WETLAND HABITATS WITHIN THE NARRAGANSETT BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE ON PRUDENCE ISLAND, RHODE ISLAND. SUPPORTED WITH THIS FUNDING IS THE DEVELOPMENT OF CONSTRUCTION PLANS, COST ESTIMATES, AND PERMIT APPLICATIONS FOR THREE HABITAT AREAS: COGGESHALL MARSH, NAG WEST MARSH, AND THE T-WHARF SHORELINE. THESE AREAS WILL PROVIDE ROOM FOR THE HABITAT TO MOVE UPLAND AS NEEDED DUE TO ACCELERATED SEA LEVEL RISE. THE CONCEPTUAL PLANS INCLUDE RESTORATION AND SEA LEVEL RISE MITIGATION MEASURES SUCH AS REROUTING COASTAL ROADS AND REMOVING INFRASTRUCTURE THAT IMPEDES MARSH MIGRATION.

NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $2,249,711.00 TO THE ELKHORN SLOUGH NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION. THIS SHOVEL-READY PROJECT WILL RESTORE THREE ICONIC COASTAL HABITATS WITHIN THE ELKHORN SLOUGH RESEARCH RESERVE, SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASING THE EXTENT OF TIDAL MARSH VEGETATION, NATIVE GRASSLAND, AND OYSTER HABITAT. THE FUNDING WILL ALLOW RESEARCH RESERVE STAFF AND PARTNERS TO INVEST HEAVILY IN RESTORATION, MONITORING, AND STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT AT THE RESERVE'S HESTER MARSH RESTORATION SITE, ADDING VALUE TO EXISTING INVESTMENTS. THIS PROJECT WILL SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASE TIDAL MARSH VEGETATION, NATIVE DOMINATED GRASSLAND, AND NATIVE OYSTER HABITAT, AS WELL AS ENGAGE A NUMBER OF COMMUNITY GROUPS, INCLUDING LOCAL NATIVE AMERICAN TRIBAL MEMBERS AND THE BROADER COASTAL MANAGEMENT COMMUNITY. THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO CREATE A CLIMATE-READY E

NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $319,730 TO MISSISSIPPI DEPARTMENT OF MARINE RESOURCES UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION.  THIS AWARD IS FOCUSED ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF A COMMUNITY STORMWATER PARK THAT WILL REDUCE FLOODING AND NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION WHILE PROVIDING RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE UNDERSERVED MOSS POINT COMMUNITY. FEDERAL FUNDING WILL BE USED TO DETERMINE THE FEASIBILITY AND IMPACT OF A STORMWATER PARK; CREATE A MAINTENANCE PLAN; CREATE DESIGNS THAT PRIORITIZE DIVERSITY, INCLUSION, AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT; AND SEEK FUNDING FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION PHASE AND PROMOTE ACTIVITIES TO CREATE A "SHOVEL-READY" PROJECT. THE PROJECT TEAM CONSISTS OF PEOPLE FROM THE GRAND BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE, THE MISSISSIPPI STATE UNIVERSITY GULF COAST COMMUNITY DESIGN STUDIO, AND MOFFAT & NICHOL ENGINEERING.

NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $2,332,854 TO WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF ECOLOGY UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION. THIS AWARD WILL RESULT IN THE PERMANENT PROTECTION OF 74.5 ACRES OF FORMER AND CURRENT TIDAL MARSH, PLUS ASSOCIATED TIDELANDS. THIS EFFORT IS PART OF A LARGER PROJECT, IN COLLABORATION WITH THE SKAGIT LAND TRUST, TO RESTORE UP TO 105 ACRES OF TIDAL MARSH TO PADILLA BAY. FOR THIS PROJECT, CRITICAL BASELINE DATA WILL ALSO BE COLLECTED, AS WELL AS AN ASSESSMENT OF RESTORATION DESIGN ALTERNATIVES. FUTURE RESTORATION AT THIS SITE WILL LIKELY INCREASE CLIMATE RESILIENCE, INCLUDING A REDUCTION IN FLOOD RISK FOR THE ONLY ROAD AND UTILITY CORRIDOR THAT SERVICES 480 HOUSES IN THE SAMISH ISLAND COMMUNITY. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO RESTORE TRIBAL CULTURAL CONNECTIONS WITH THE SITE, WHICH IS NEAR AN IMPORTANT HISTORICAL LONGHOUSE LOCATION. ACCESS TO THE AREA, AND THE NATURAL R

NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $1,272,383 TO UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA ANCHORAGE UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION. THROUGH A PARTNERSHIP WITH THE KACHEMAK BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE, THE CITY OF HOMER WILL ACQUIRE 55 ACRES OF PEATLAND, AN AREA THAT PROVIDES HABITAT FOR MOOSE, BEAR, AND OTHER FISH AND COASTAL WILDLIFE, AND IMPROVES WATER QUALITY FOR SALMON AND OTHER FISH. THE PEATLAND WILL ALSO SERVE AS A NATURE-BASED SOLUTION FOR STORMWATER COLLECTION. THIS WORK WILL SIMULTANEOUSLY RECHARGE WATER LEVELS IN THE PEAT, PROTECT THE WATER QUALITY OF KACHEMAK BAY, AND MITIGATE COASTAL EROSION.

NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $3,535,900 TO OREGON DEPARTMENT OF STATE LANDS UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION. THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF STATE LANDS WILL RESTORE THE ECOLOGICAL HEALTH OF AND CULTURAL CONNECTIONS WITH THE WASSON CREEK WATERSHED IN THE SOUTH SLOUGH NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE. OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE RE-ESTABLISHMENT OF RESILIENT WETLANDS, STREAMS, TIDAL FORESTED SWAMPS, AND UPLAND FOREST HABITATS. THESE RESTORED SYSTEMS WILL PROVIDE HABITAT FOR A VARIETY OF ECOLOGICALLY AND CULTURALLY IMPORTANT FISH SPECIES, HAVE HIGH BLUE CARBON STORAGE BENEFITS, SUPPORT SUSTAINABLE HARVESTING FOR INDIGENOUS CULTURAL PRACTICES, AND PROVIDE A SEED SOURCE FOR LOCAL RESTORATION PROJECTS.

NOAA IS AWARDING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $3,976,788 TO WASHINGTON STATE DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION UNDER THE FY2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION COMPETITION. THIS AWARD WILL RESULT IN THE RESTORATION AND PROTECTION OF GRAVEYARD SPIT ON THE NORTH SHORE OF WILLAPA BAY, WASHINGTON, THROUGH THE REHABILITATION AND REVEGETATION OF THE HISTORIC BARRIER DUNE; THE CONSTRUCTION OF A NATURE-BASED COBBLE BERM (ALSO KNOWN AS A DYNAMIC REVETMENT); AND THE PROTECTION AND RESTORATION OF BACKSHORE MARSH AND TIDAL EMBAYMENT ENVIRONMENTS. THE PROJECT IS A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE LOCAL COMMUNITIES OF NORTH COVE, TOKELAND, AND PACIFIC COUNTY; THE SHOALWATER BAY INDIAN TRIBE; THE STATE OF WASHINGTON; AND THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS.

THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) IS PROVIDING $450,000 IN FUNDING TO THE STATE OF RHODE ISLAND THROUGH THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW OVER THE NEXT THREE YEARS. THIS FUNDING WILL BUILD THE CAPACITY OF THE JOBOS BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE (JOBOS BAY NERR) WITHIN THE PUERTO RICO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES TO PLAN FOR AND IMPLEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION PROJECTS PROPOSED THROUGH FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES CONNECTED TO THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW. SPECIFICALLY, BAY NERR WILL USE THESE FUNDS TO WORK WITH PARTNERS, CONSULTANTS, CONTRACTORS AND OTHERS TO COMPLETE SITE ASSESSMENTS, TRAIN STAFF, CREATE PRE- AND POST-PROJECT MONITORING PROTOCOLS AND PLANS, CONCEPTUAL AND SITE DESIGNS, PROJECT BUDGETS, FACILITATE PERMIT REQUIREMENTS AND SUPPORT NEPA ASSESSMENTS FOR TWO PRIORITY HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS. THE TWO HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS THAT HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED ARE: 1) RESTORATION OF THE AREA OF CAMINO DEL INDIO IMPACTED BY ILLEGAL DEVELOPMENT WITHIN THE JOBOS BAY NERR; AND 2) RESTORATION OF THE AGUIRRE FOREST IMPACTED BY HURRICANE MARIA. THE CONTRACTOR WILL ALSO IDENTIFY LANDS TO BE ACQUIRED TO IMPROVE RESILIENCE OF COMMUNITIES VULNERABLE TO INUNDATION FROM STORMS AND FLOODS.

THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) IS PROVIDING $450,000 IN FEDERAL FUNDING TO THE STATE OF INDIANA THROUGH THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW OVER THE NEXT THREE YEARS. THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) IS PROVIDING $450,000 IN FEDERAL FUNDING TO THE STATE OF MARYLAND THROUGH THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW OVER THE NEXT THREE YEARS. THIS FUNDING WILL BUILD THE CAPACITY OF MARYLAND'S FEDERALLY-APPROVED COASTAL MANAGEMENT PROGRAM WITHIN THE DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES TO PLAN FOR AND IMPLEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION PROJECTS PROPOSED THROUGH FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES CONNECTED TO THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW. THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) IS PROVIDING $447,212 IN FEDERAL FUNDING TO THE STATE OF VIRGINIA THROUGH THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW OVER THE NEXT THREE YEARS. THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) IS PROVIDING $300,000 IN FEDERAL FUNDING TO THE STATE OF TEXAS THROUGH THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW OVER THE NEXT THREE YEARS. THIS FUNDING WILL BUILD THE CAPACITY OF THE MISSION-ARANSAS NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE (MANERR) WITHIN THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS  TO PLAN FOR AND IMPLEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION PROJECTS PROPOSED THROUGH FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES CONNECTED TO THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW. SPECIFICALLY, MISSION-ARANSAS NERR WILL USE THESE FUNDS TO CREATE A NEW STAFF POSITION, AND HIRE A FULL-TIME RESTORATION SPECIALIST. THIS POSITION WILL INCREASE THE RESERVE'S ABILITY TO PLAN FOR AND IMPLEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION PROJECTS WITHIN THE MISSION-ARANSAS NERR.  THIS NEW 'RESTORATION SPECIALIST' POSITION WILL ALSO BE KEY IN IDENTIFYING AND DEVELOPING PARTNERSHIPS AND COLLABORATIONS FOCUSED ON HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION PROJECTS WITHIN OR SURROUNDING THE RESERVE.

THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) IS PROVIDING $300,000 IN FEDERAL FUNDING TO THE STATE OF FLORIDA THROUGH THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW OVER THE NEXT THREE YEARS. THIS FUNDING WILL BUILD THE CAPACITY OF THE ROOKERY BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE WITHIN THE FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION TO PLAN FOR AND IMPLEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION PROJECTS PROPOSED THROUGH FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES CONNECTED TO THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW. SPECIFICALLY, THE ROOKERY BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE PROPOSES TO MEET THIS GOAL BY DEVELOPING MONITORING PROTOCOLS AND ASSOCIATED PERFORMANCE MEASURES WHICH CAN BE USED TO TRAIN CITIZEN SCIENTISTS TO CONDUCT PRE AND POST MONITORING FOR HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS AT ROOKERY BAY NERR.  THE MULTIYEAR EFFORT WILL GUIDE A CITIZEN SCIENCE MONITORING PROGRAM THROUGH HIRING A COORDINATOR AND CONSULTANT WHO WILL WORK TOGETHER TO DEVELOP A SPECIFIC PLAN THAT MEETS MONITORING REQUIREMENTS AND PROVIDES TIMELY INFORMATION ABOUT THE ECOSYSTEM. ONCE HIRED, THE MONITORING COORDINATOR WILL DEVELOP A RESTORATION MONITORING PROTOCOL AND TARGET PERFORMANCE MEASURES APPLICABLE FOR THE UPCOMING HYDROLOGICAL HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS OCCURRING ON RESERVE MANAGED LANDS (MARCO SHORES AND SHELL ISLAND ROAD). ONCE THE PROTOCOL IS ESTABLISHED, THE COORDINATOR WILL DEVELOP AND DELIVER TRAINING WORKSHOPS TO INTERESTED COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND RESERVE VOLUNTEERS. THIS WILL SUPPORT EDUCATION AND OUTREACH WITH COMMUNITIES PRIOR TO RESTORATION DEVELOPMENT AND ALLOW THE COMMUNITY TO DIRECTLY MEASURE BENEFITS OF RESTORATION. A STUDENT INTERNSHIP WILL BE OFFERED EACH SUMMER FOR AN UNDERSERVED STUDENT AS AN OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN MORE ABOUT A CAREER IN NATURAL SCIENCES (HABITAT RESTORATION) OR SOCIAL SCIENCES (CITIZEN SCIENCE AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT).

THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) IS PROVIDING $450,000 IN FEDERAL FUNDING TO THE STATE OF GEORGIA  THROUGH THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW OVER THE NEXT THREE YEARS. SPECIFICALLY, THE GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES WILL USE THESE FUNDS TO ENSURE RESOURCES ARE AVAILABLE TO EFFECTIVELY SUPPORT AND IMPLEMENT ACQUISITION, RESTORATION AND INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS IN GEORGIA'S COASTAL ZONE. SPECIFICALLY, THE FUNDING SOUGHT WILL BE USED TO HIRE AN ADDITIONAL BIOLOGIST DEDICATED TO SUPPORTING IIJA PROJECTS, WHILE ALSO DEVELOPING NEW ACQUISITION OR RESTORATION PROJECTS AND CREATING LONG-TERM STRATEGIES TO ENSURE BEST MANAGEMENT AND RESILIENCE PRACTICES ARE INCORPORATED INTO INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS. COASTAL INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS ARE COMPLEX AND INVOLVE FREQUENT COMMUNICATION AND COLLABORATION OVER MULTIPLE YEARS. THE GCMP WILL WORK WITH COASTAL PROJECTS THROUGHOUT THEIR DURATION TO ENSURE COASTAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND RESILIENCY CONCEPTS ARE INCORPORATED IN PLANNING, DESIGN, AND CONSTRUCTION.

THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) IS PROVIDING $298,262 IN FEDERAL FUNDING TO HAWAII THROUGH THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW OVER THE NEXT THREE YEARS. THIS FUNDING WILL BUILD THE CAPACITY OF THE HE'EIA NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE (NERR) WITHIN UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII TO PLAN FOR AND IMPLEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION PROJECTS PROPOSED THROUGH FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES CONNECTED TO THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW. SPECIFICALLY, HE'EIA NERR WILL USE THESE FUNDS TO INCREASE THE RESERVE'S AND PARTNER CAPACITY TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE INCOMING PROJECT FUNDS IN THE REALM OF PROGRAM MANAGEMENT, ACCOUNTING, AND HUMAN RESOURCES THROUGH THE HIRING STAFF AT THE NERR AND THEIR LAND MANAGEMENT PARTNER.

THE MAIN PROJECT OBJECTIVE IS TO ENHANCE THE CURRENT CAPABILITIES OF CURRENT HYDRODYNAMIC MODEL ENGINES BY DEVELOPING 3D CAPABILITIES (I.E., STRATIFICATION) AND APPLY THE MODEL TO OUTSIDE THE CONTINENTAL U.S. (OCONUS) AND SURGE FOR EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS. THIS WILL INCLUDE PROBABILISTIC CAPABILITIES AND EXPLORING DATA ASSIMILATION CAPABILITIES.  SPECIFICALLY, EXPLORATION WILL INCLUDE MODEL ENGINES AND DEVELOPMENT OF 3D CAPABILITIES (I.E., STRATIFICATION) IN ORDER TO PROVIDE AN INFRASTRUCTURE THAT CAN SUPPORT COASTAL AND OCEAN MODELS THAT EXTEND FROM THE OCEAN BASIN (DEEP OCEAN WATERS) THROUGH THE COASTAL ZONE AND UP TO THE LAND WATERSHED NETWORK (RIVERINE).

IN RESPONSE TO THE DIRECTION SET FORTH IN THE INFRASTRUCTURE INVESTMENTS AND JOBS ACT, 2022 (P.L. 117-58), THE NATIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE FOUNDATION (NFWF) PROPOSES TO PARTNER WITH THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) TO SUPPORT COASTAL RESILIENCY PROJECTS THAT WILL HELP PROTECT COASTAL COMMUNITIES FROM THE IMPACTS OF STORMS AND FLOODS AND ENABLE THEM TO RECOVER MORE QUICKLY, WHILE ALSO ENHANCING HABITATS FOR IMPORTANT FISH AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS. THESE MULTI-YEAR PROJECTS WILL INVEST IN A PIPELINE OF PROJECTS THAT WILL DIRECTLY RESULT IN RESTORATION OR EXPANSION OF NATURAL FEATURES LIKE DUNES, WETLANDS, REEFS, RIPARIAN BUFFERS, AND BARRIER ISLANDS THAT HELP TO REDUCE THE IMPACTS OF FUTURE STORMS AND OTHER NATURALLY OCCURRING EVENTS ON HUMAN, FISH, AND WILDLIFE COMMUNITIES. THIS PARTNERSHIP WAS DEVELOPED IN ACCORDANCE WITH SECTION 906(C) OF TITLE IX OF P.L. 114-113 (16 U.S.C. 7505(C)).

NA WAA MAUO- PROJECT HANAU KA UKU KOAKOA, A HONUAIAKEA VOYAGING EXPERIENCE WILL USE WAA (OUTRIGGER CANOES) TO EXAMINE THE EFFECTS OF MICROPLASTICS TO PLANKTON ECOLOGY IN NEARSHORE AREAS OF THE HILO ONE ESTUARY. STUDENT RESEARCH WILL INVESTIGATE PLANKTON LIFE THROUGH THE LENS OF THE KUMULIPO (HAWAIIAN CREATION CHANT). HANAU KA UKU KOAKOA, HANAU KANA, HE AKOAKOA, PUKA (BORN IS THE CORAL FLEA, AND A CORAL HEAD WAS BORN). PARTICIPANTS WILL COMBINE INDIGENOUS AND INSTITUTIONAL SCIENCE TO DEVELOP AND EXECUTE RESEARCH AND ENVIRONMENTAL ACTION PROJECTS. THE HANAU KA UKU KOAKOA PROJECT WILL TAKE PLACE IN FOUR PHASES. IN PHASE 1, TEACHERS DEVELOP AN ESSENTIAL RESEARCH QUESTION, LEARN ABOUT THE STUDY SITE AND THE HONUAIAKEA VOYAGING PROGRAM MODEL. DURING PHASE 2, TEACHERS LEAD A RESEARCH EXPERIENCE IMMERSING STUDENTS IN THE SCIENTIFIC PROCESS. IN PHASE 3, STUDENTS IMPLEMENT THEIR OWN RESEARCH AND SHARE THEIR FINDINGS WITH THEIR COMMUNITY. FINALLY, IN PHASE 4, STUDENTS PLAN AND IMPLEMENT ENVIRONME

MAUKA TO MAKAI: WATERSHED EXPERIENCE FOR TEACHERS (M2M:WET) PROJECT SEEKS TO ENHANCE THE CAPACITY OF HAWAII'S SECONDARY-LEVEL SCIENCE TEACHERS TO ENGAGE THEIR STUDENTS IN WATERSHED AND AHUPUAA STEWARDSHIP EDUCATION. THE TWO-YEAR PROJECT WILL BRING TOGETHER TEACHERS WORKING IN HAWAII SCHOOLS (I.E. GRADES 6-12) TO BUILD CAPACITY TO STEWARD URBAN WATERSHEDS FROM MAUKA TO MAKAI THROUGH AN IN-DEPTH PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FIELD EXPERIENCE. THE TARGET NUMBER OF TEACHERS IS 18, WITH A COMBINED IMPACT OF APPROXIMATELY 2,700 STUDENTS/YEAR. THE M2M:WET TWO-WEEK FIELD EXPERIENCE WILL EMPLOY THE HAWAIIAN PRACTICE OF KILO (KEEN OBSERVATION) AND SCIENTIFIC SKILLS. THE TEACHERS WILL THEN DEVELOP TEACHING MATERIALS, THROUGH ACTIVITIES WITH CUH FACULTY (INCLUDING A HAWAIIAN CULTURAL SPECIALIST) AND PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS. FOLLOWING THE SUMMER FIELD EXPERIENCE, TEACHERS WILL ENGAGE IN COMMUNITY-BUILDING MEETINGS, CURRICULUM DEVELOPMENT AND SUPPORT, AND PRESENT THEIR WORK AT A CONFERENCE.

THE KOOLAUPOKO IMPACT COLLECTIVE: KAWAINUI YOUTH STEWARDSHIP PROGRAM AIMS TO BE THE HUB FOR WINDWARD WATERSHED LEARNING AND STEWARDSHIP BY CONNECTING LOCAL AND INTERNATIONAL YOUTH WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS, AND THROUGH COORDINATING OPPORTUNITIES MULTI-AGE COLLABORATION AND EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING WORK. LE JARDIN ACADEMY IS POSITIONED TO FACILITATE MEANINGFUL KOOLAUPOKO WATERSHED EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING AND SUSTAINED YOUTH STEWARDSHIP. THROUGH THE CONTINUED DEVELOPMENT AND MANAGEMENT OF THE KOOLAUPOKO IMPACT COLLECTIVE (KIC) LJA WILL: FACILITATE AND ACTIVATE A KAWAINUI YOUTH STEWARDSHIP CERTIFICATION COURSE FOR KOOLAUPOKO YOUTH, CONNECT LOCAL AND INTERNATIONAL YOUTH WITH WATERSHED COMMUNITY PARTNERS, COORDINATE AND LEAD IMPACTFUL WATERSHED WORK AND RELEVANT CIVIC ENGAGEMENT, AND ADVANCE KOOLAUPOKO'S SERVICE OF UNITED NATIONS' SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT GOALS.

THE IOLANI PAEPAE O WAI EKOLU: PLACE-BASED WATERSHED EDUCATION AND CARING FOR STREAM ECOSYSTEMS PROJECT WILL EDUCATE THE PUBLIC ABOUT HAWAII'S NATIVE UNIQUE FRESHWATER SPECIES AND THE EFFECT OF HUMAN INFLUENCE ON THEIR POPULATIONS. IOLANI SCHOOL INITIATED A STREAM OUTREACH AND RESTORATION PROJECT WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII AT MANOA. TOGETHER, CLASSROOM CURRICULUM AND FIELD PROTOCOLS WERE DEVELOPED FOR USE IN K-12 PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SCHOOLS ON OAHU, EMPHASIZING ENVIRONMENTAL AWARENESS THROUGH FOUR SEQUENTIAL FRESHWATER STREAM AND WATERSHED LESSONS. LESSONS BEGIN WITH AN INTRODUCTION TO NATIVE/NON-NATIVE STREAM ANIMALS AND HOW THEY ARE INDICATORS OF STREAM HEALTH. STUDENTS THEN LEARN HOW TO WORK TOGETHER TO CAPTURE STREAM ANIMALS IN A STANDARDIZED SURVEY METHOD CALLED PAEPAE. AFTER REHEARSING THEIR FIELD METHODS, STUDENTS ARE TAKEN TO A NEARBY STREAM SITE FOR FIELD APPLICATION. THE FINAL LESSON INVOLVES A DATA EXPLORATION SCIENCE CURRICULUM THAT HAS BEEN DESIGNED TO FIT THE NEXT GENER

THE PILINA KAIAULU PROGRAM: IMMERSIVE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR ENGAGING CLIMATE CHANGE, WATERSHED HEALTH, AND BIOCULTURAL STEWARDSHIP WILL PROVIDE AN IMMERSIVE, PLACE-BASED PROGRAMMING TO SUPPORT BIOCULTURALLY-BASED, STEM FOCUSED, AND CAREER-CONNECTED LEARNING FOR HAWAII'S YOUTH, AND INTENSIVE, SEMESTER LONG PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMMING FOR THEIR TEACHERS. BUILDING ON A DECADE OF WORK IN THESE AREAS, TEACHING CHANGE NOW PROPOSES THE PILINA KAIAULU (COMMUNITY RELATIONSHIP) PROGRAM, AN INNOVATIVE TWO-YEAR SERIES OF EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES DESIGNED TO FOSTER BIOCULTURAL LEARNING INTO MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES (MWEES) FOR TEACHERS AND THEIR STUDENTS. THIS PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE: (1) LEARNING AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT THAT IS GROUNDED IN THE PLACES WHERE TEACHERS AND STUDEN

THE WISDOM OF THE WATERSHED PHASE II WILL INCREASE ENGAGEMENT OF HAWAII'S YOUTH IN EARTH AND OCEAN SCIENCES AND STEWARDSHIP EXPERIENCES. BY ENGAGING STUDENTS IN THE RESEARCH PROCESS AND BRIDGING OUT-OF-SCHOOL ACTIVITIES TO CLASSROOM LESSONS, STUDENTS WILL BE BETTER PREPARED FOR STUDIES IN SECONDARY AND POST-SECONDARY SCIENCE, AND CAREERS IN THE NATURAL SCIENCES. THIS PROGRAM CREATES AND LEVERAGES ESTABLISHED SUSTAINABLE CONNECTIONS BETWEEN TEACHERS AND RESEARCHERS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII, PUBLIC AGENCIES, AND PRIVATE BUSINESSES. BY GUIDING STUDENT AND TEACHER PARTICIPATION IN ACTIVITIES THAT SUPPORT LEADING-EDGE RESEARCH QUESTIONS CONCERNING LOCAL COMMUNITIES, STUDENTS WILL BECOME COMMUNITY-READY TO ASSIST LOCAL CIVIC AND SCIENTIFIC ACTION. THE KA UA NAULU O KAWAIHAE: STRENGTHENING RELATIONS MA UKA (MOUNTAINS) TO MA KAI (OCEAN) AS AHUPUAA-STEWARDED LEARNERS PROJECT WILL TRAIN WEST HAWAII TEACHERS TO PROVIDE MWEES IN AHUPUAA STEWARDSHIP IN THE OUTDOOR CLASSROOM OF THE AHUPUAA OF KAWAIHAE AND THE WATERSHED OF HONOKOA. TEACHERS WILL LEARN FOUR ESSENTIAL AHUPUAA STEWARDSHIP PRACTICES BASED IN INDIGENOUS AND LOCAL KNOWLEDGE-HOOLAUNA, KILO, HANA, AND MOOLELO-AS WELL AS TRADITIONAL CONSERVATION PRACTICES THROUGH OUTDOOR HOAAINA (CARETAKER OF THE LAND) EXPERIENCES, KUKAKUKA (TALK-STORY DISCUSSION) SESSIONS, AND CLASSROOM INTEGRATION MODELING WORKSHOPS. FOLLOWING TRAINING, TEACHERS WILL HAVE A FIVE MONTH PERIOD TO EXECUTE MWEES WITH ONGOING SUPPORT FROM THE KOHALA CENTER. THE PERFORMANCE-BASED ASSESSMENT WILL HELP IDENTIFY KEY INDICATORS OF HEALTHY ECOSYSTEMS WITHIN OUR RESPECTIVE AHUPUAA, KEY CONDITIONS THAT STRENGTHEN HA (HAWAIIAN UNDERSTANDING OF BREATH) AND NA HOPENA AO (HA) EDUCATIONAL SYSTEM-LEVEL OUTCOMES IN AINA AND KANAKA

THE CHAMPIONS OF COASTAL RESILIENCE: DEVELOPING CLIMATE STEWARDS & CARING FOR OUR COASTAL COMMUNITIES IS A STATEWIDE INITIATIVE THAT SEEKS TO DEVELOP CLIMATE STEWARDS THAT WILL HELP CARE FOR COASTAL COMMUNITIES. RESILIENCE IS DEFINED AS THE CAPACITY TO ANTICIPATE AND PLAN FOR CHANGE, RESIST DAMAGE, RAPIDLY RECOVER, AND ADAPT TO CHANGING CONDITIONS. AS A RESULT OF CLIMATE CHANGE, COASTAL RESILIENCE TAKES ON A NEW LEVEL OF IMPORTANCE AS PROJECTED SEA LEVEL RISE AND INTENSIFICATION OF STORMS PRESENT CHALLENGES SUCH AS EROSION AND FLOODING. LEARNING ENDEAVORS AND PARTNERS BELIEVE AN ESSENTIAL PART OF THE SOLUTION IS EMPOWERING YOUTH THROUGH INNOVATIVE EDUCATION AND LEADERSHIP OPPORTUNITIES.

IN RESPONSE TO THE DIRECTION SET FORTH IN THE CONSOLIDATED APPROPRIATIONS ACT, 2022 (P.L. 117-103), THE NATIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE FOUNDATION (NFWF) PROPOSES TO PARTNER WITH NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) TO SUPPORT TO SUPPORT COASTAL RESILIENCE PROJECTS THAT WILL HELP PROTECT COASTAL COMMUNITIES FROM THE IMPACTS OF STORMS AND FLOODS AND ENABLE THEM TO RECOVER MORE QUICKLY, WHILE ALSO ENHANCING HABITATS FOR IMPORTANT FISH AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS. NFWF WILL ALSO STRATEGICALLY SUPPORT INNOVATIVE BEST PRACTICES TO INFORM FUTURE PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION OF NATURAL SYSTEMS TO ENHANCE COASTAL COMMUNITY RESILIENCE. THESE MULTI-YEAR PROJECTS WILL INVEST IN A PIPELINE OF PROJECTS THAT WILL DIRECTLY RESULT IN RESTORATION OR EXPANSION OF NATURAL FEATURES LIKE DUNES, WETLANDS, REEFS, RIPARIAN BUFFERS, AND BARRIER ISLANDS THAT MINIMIZE THE IMPACTS OF FUTURE STORMS AND OTHER NATURALLY OCCURRING EVENTS ON HUMAN, FISH, AND WILDLIFE COMMUNITIES. THE GULF OF MEXICO ALLIANCE (GOMA) WILL SUPPORT GOMA'S UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS FROM UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS IN PAID INTERNSHIPS AT GOMA'S PARTNER STATE AGENCIES. THE GOMA IS IN A UNIQUE POSITION TO REDUCE BARRIERS AND CREATE OPPORTUNITIES FOR CAREER GROWTH THROUGH NETWORKING, MENTORING, PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRAINING, AND HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE. TO SUPPORT UNDERREPRESENTED AND UNDERSERVED GROUPS, GOMA HAS IDENTIFIED INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITIES AS A WAY TO ENGAGE EARLY CAREER SCIENTISTS AND STUDENTS.  PARTICIPANTS FROM DIVERSE BACKGROUNDS ACROSS THE FIVE GULF STATES (ALABAMA, FLORIDA, LOUISIANA, MISSISSIPPI, AND TEXAS) WILL GAIN MENTORING AND HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE IN COASTAL MANAGEMENT CAREERS. INTERNSHIP TOPICS MAY INCLUDE: COASTAL COMMUNITY RESILIENCE, DATA SHARING, HABITAT RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT, WATER RESOURCES, AND WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES. NOAA'S NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE (NOS) AND THE COASTAL STATES ORGANIZATION (CSO) HAVE A LONG HISTORY OF WORKING TOGETHER TO ADVANCE COASTAL MANAGEMENT IN THE UNITED STATES. THIS NEW COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT, FOR FY2022-2025, BUILDS OFF THE WORK UNDER THE PREVIOUS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT (FY2019-2021) AND FORMALLY CONTINUES A SUCCESSFUL PARTNERSHIP ON COASTAL MANAGEMENT ISSUES, WITH A FOCUS ON COASTAL RESILIENCE ACTIVITIES IN THE GREAT LAKES, AS WELL AS PRIORITIES IDENTIFIED WITHIN THE 2018-2023 NATIONAL COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIC PLAN AND THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE ADMINISTRATION'S EXECUTIVE ORDERS (EO) 14008 (TACKLING CLIMATE CHANGE AT HOME AND ABROAD) AND 13985 (ADVANCING RACIAL EQUITY AND SUPPORT FOR UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES THROUGH THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT).

IN RESPONSE TO THE DIRECTION SET FORTH IN THE EXTENDING GOVERNMENT FUNDING AND DELIVERING EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE ACT, 2022 (P.L. 117-43), THE NATIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE FOUNDATION (NFWF) IS PARTNERING WITH THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) TO SUPPORT PROJECTS THAT INCREASE THE RESILIENCE OF COASTAL COMMUNITIES IMPACTED BY HURRICANES AND WILDFIRES IN 2020 AND 2021. THE 2021 EMERGENCY COASTAL RESILIENCE FUND (ECRF) WILL SUPPORT PROJECTS THAT CREATE AND RESTORE NATURAL SYSTEMS TO HELP PROTECT COASTAL COMMUNITIES FROM THE IMPACTS OF COASTAL STORMS, FLOODS, SEA-LEVEL RISE, INUNDATION, COASTAL EROSION, WILDFIRES AND ASSOCIATED LANDSLIDES/DEBRIS FLOWS, AND ENABLE COMMUNITIES TO RECOVER MORE QUICKLY FROM THESE EVENTS, ALL WHILE IMPROVING HABITATS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES. THIS PARTNERSHIP WAS DEVELOPED IN ACCORDANCE WITH SECTION 906(C) OF TITLE IX OF P.L. 114-113 (16 U.S.C. 7505(C)).

THE PROPOSED FUTURE FORESTERS MAUKA MAKAI STEWARDSHIP PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE MEANINGFUL EXPERIENCES FOR STUDENTS THAT WILL LEAD TO A LIFETIME OF LEARNING AND ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP. THE PROGRAM EXPANDS UPON THE WAIKOLOA DRY FOREST INITIATIVES (WDFI) ESTABLISHED FUTURE FORESTERS AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAM TO INCREASE IMMERSIVE WATERSHED LEARNING AND IMPACTFUL EXPERIENCES IN OUR REGIONS STORIED AHUPUAA FOR LOCAL FOURTH AND FIFTH GRADE STUDENTS. THROUGH FIELD-BASED EXPLORATION, THE WDFI AND COLLABORATORS WILL CONNECT KEIKI WITH NATIVE FORESTS AND COASTLINES TO LEARN AND EXPERIENCE THE PATH OF WAI IN OUR ENVIRONMENT. LEARNERS WILL FORGE THEIR OWN PATHS TOWARDS ENVISIONING A HEALTHY, MODERN-DAY WATERSHED AND DISCOVERING THEIR ROLES IN STEWARDING THAT PLACE. THIS WEEKLY AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAM WILL ALLOW STUDENTS TO ACQUIRE A DEEPER UNDERSTANDING OF THE ROLE OF THE NATIVE ECOSYSTEMS IN OUR REGION AND EMPOWER THEM WITH THE KNOWLEDGE AND TOOLS THEY WILL NEED TO CARE FOR OUR NATIVE LANDS AND WATERS

THE BOYS & GIRLS CLUB OF HAWAII'S ALOHA AINA PROGRAM IS A PLACE/CULTURE-BASED CURRICULUM COUPLED WITH MEANINGFUL OUTDOOR FIELD EXPERIENCES WHICH EDUCATES YOUTH ON ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION BY FOSTERING STEWARDSHIP OF THE NANAKULI-WAIANAE COMPLEX AND ITS AHUPUAA, SERVING 120 YOUTHS AGES 9-14. WHILE UTILIZING A HYBRID PROGRAM OF IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL LEARNING WHILE INCORPORATING FIELD COMPONENTS, THIS PROJECT INCREASES YOUTHS KNOWLEDGE AND INSPIRES THEM ABOUT CAREERS IN S.T.E.M. (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, AND MATH).

THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CREATE A PROTOTYPE STATEWIDE AINA-BASED EDUCATION CERTIFICATION PROGRAM FOR TEACHERS AND STUDENTS TO SUPPORT AND GROW THE FIELD OF AINA-BASED EDUCATION AS A RIGHTFUL AND RECOGNIZED PROFESSION. MALAMA LEARNING CENTER WILL PARTNER WITH HAWAII ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION ALLIANCE TO DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT A PILOT PROGRAM WITH GUIDANCE FROM THE NORTH AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION. THE PROGRAM WILL SERVE BOTH FORMAL AND INFORMAL EDUCATORS AS WELL AS STUDENTS GRADES 10 AND UP. MWEE WILL BE A PILLAR FOR CERTIFICATION FOR BOTH EDUCATORS AND STUDENTS. INCLUSIVITY WILL BE FUNDAMENTAL, POTENTIALLY REACHING TEACHERS AND STUDENTS FROM ALL COMMUNITIES THROUGHOUT HAWAII AND INVOLVING A WIDE RANGE OF PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS TO PROVIDE OUTDOOR AND HANDS-ON TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES. WHILE THIS PROJECT IS CENTERED ON PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, ITS IMPACT COULD BE SYSTEMIC, ELEVATING THE PROMINENCE OF ABE AND MAKING IT MORE ACCESSIBLE AND RESPECTED AS A PROFE
CHAMPIONS OF COASTAL RESILIENCE: A COASTAL FIELD ECOLOGY PROGRAM FOR HIGH SCHOOLS

THIS PROJECT WILL TRAIN HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS IN MULTIPLE WAYS TO VISUALLY ASSESS THE HEALTH OF THE HONOULIULI WATERSHED AND THE GREATER AREA OF THE HONOULIULI AHUPUA`A. THROUGH EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING ACTIVITIES INCLUDING CULTURALLY GROUNDED KILO OBSERVATION PRACTICES, VISUAL STREAM ASSESSMENT PROTOCOLS DEVELOPED BY THE USDA AND GIS TECHNOLOGY, STUDENTS WILL GAIN THE SKILLS AND UNDERSTANDING TO ASSESS ANY WATERSHED THEY ENCOUNTER THROUGHOUT THEIR LIFETIME. THE TECHNIQUES STUDENTS LEARN WILL BE APPLIED TO THE HONOULIULI WATERSHED IN A FIELD EXPERIENCE THAT INCLUDES OPPORTUNITIES TO REMOVE INVASIVE VEGETATION AND PLANT NATIVE WETLAND SPECIES. IN ADDITION TO HANDS-ON FIELD EXPERIENCES, THIS PROJECT INCLUDES MULTIPLE PATHWAYS FOR CONTINUED STUDENT STEWARDSHIP THAT ADDRESS ONE OR MORE OBSERVED HUMAN DISTURBANCES THAT IMPACT THE MAKAI (NEAREST THE OCEAN) PORTION OF THE HONOULIULI WATERSHED.

STUDENTS WILL WORK WITH THE ENTIRE WATERSHED-TOP, MIDDLE, AND OCEAN SECTIONS, MAUKA TO MAKAI, RIDGE TO REEF)- OF WAIKOLOA AND KAMAKOA TO ENGAGE IN MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES INCLUDING HANDS-ON SCIENCE, SOCIAL STUDIES, MATH, AND LANGUAGE ARTS ACTIVITIES. THE PROGRAM'S DESIGN WHICH INTEGRATES CULTURE, PLACE, COMMUNITY, AND SCIENCE THROUGH STUDENT DRIVEN PROJECTS CREATES A MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE THAT INCREASES THE STUDENTS' UNDERSTANDING AND THEIR MOTIVATION TO CONTINUE TO TAKE CARE OF THEIR LOCAL WATERSHED IN YEARS TO COME.
